content:
Constraints state 1 <= N[i] but it seems that there is no testcase or validator where wrongly classifying 1 as a prime number results in a wrong answer.

This is particularly problematic in Shortest mode, where someone who wrongly classifies 1 as a prime number would probably win over someone who writes the (probably longer) correct version.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It looks like it will work well in all CoC modes and is well defined.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice problem

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Love it! Slight inefficiency, it seems like you have to print the bigger number that repeats (in reverse)
Thanks for all the feedback, I've now changed it to include fastest and shortest aswell.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I find the idea interesting and I think it could be present in all modes
I feel like this is good in Shortest mode

Test cases are poorly designed. I think most people will be able to figure out something about repeating numbers within a minute or two. So, I pretended to be ignorant and searched for the first duplicate number. Voila! I pass all test cases! Let's submit! And so everyone in the CoC will get 80% success because validator #1's first repeated number is not prime (incidentally, val #1 is the only one of your tests/validators where the naive method doesn't work).

Here's my recommended test suite:
(1) 4 numbers, where 3 is the only duplicate
(2) 8 numbers, with two prime duplicates, and 7 is the first repeated number
(3) 8 numbers, with two duplicates and 6 is the first repeated number while 11 is the second
(4) 10 numbers, with three duplicates, the first of which is even, the second of which is odd but not prime, and the last is prime
(5) whatever you want, with N = 25 or so
(6) whatever you want, with N = 100 or so

I'm not a big fan of 10 <= N since there's so much information, but if you have strong feelings about keeping it that way, I'm okay with it.
Just to make it clear, the goal is to find the duplicate prime number. Non-prime numbers may be duplicate, but there is only one pair of duplicate prime numbers.

Thanks for the feedback!

I totally agree on the test cases, I hadn't thought about the order of the duplicates, and that you get 80% with just looking for the first ones. 
The test cases are randomly generated with the rules in mind, so it is just a coincidence that it is so. I will fix that!

Yes, I did think about having N be large could be a problem, and maybe not necessary. Definitly something I was looking for feedback on. 

I think your suggestions for the test cases are all valid, so I've implemented those now. Take a look and see if you agree :)

Yes, I second this idea, since the test cases are easily interpretable about the repeatability of prime numbers, I suggest this to be placed under Shortest mode, it will be a good challenge to pick two prime numbers which are repeating with minimum code.
I agree with this. Reverse mode would be an interesting one to figure out, with medium-sized test cases (5-20).
Almost, but not for test case 4. I've changed test case 3 to reflect this as well, so it's more clear.
